comments.body_markdown: @TheImpaler Pardon my ignorance, but do you have any resources showing how Dynamic SQL could help here? A few searches didn't net me anything helpful.
comments.body: @TheImpaler Pardon my ignorance, but do you have any resources showing how Dynamic SQL could help here? A few searches didn't net me anything helpful.

comments.body_markdown: Dynamic SQL is essentially the old way of concatenating strings to assemble a running query. This is highly unsafe, of course, and can be susceptible of SQL Injection. On the other hand, you are trying to **apply** a parameter using the `?` syntax. This syntax is always safe, but it does not cover all possible cases. One of them is your case.
comments.body: Dynamic SQL is essentially the old way of concatenating strings to assemble a running query. This is highly unsafe, of course, and can be susceptible of SQL Injection. On the other hand, you are trying to apply a parameter using the ? syntax. This syntax is always safe, but it does not cover all possible cases. One of them is your case.

answers.body_markdown:
I think there is a possibility to make this case a real false positive by using concatenation. You need to produce a statement where the value is surrounded by double quotes. That is, produce this kind of statement:

```
SELECT NEXTVAL FOR "variable part".CNTCT_ID FROM SYSIBM.SYSDUMMY1
```

In this case DB2 is forced to consider the variable part as the schema name of the sequence.

This is provided that the value does not itself contain a double quote.

And this implies that the schema name value is now case sensitive.

In this case DB2 is forced to consider the variable part as the schema name of the sequence.

<!-- begin snippet: js hide: false console: true babel: false -->

<!-- language: lang-js -->

    spring:
      profiles:
        active: dev
      application:
        name: APP_GATEWAY
      cloud:
        gateway:
          routes:
            - id: users
              uri: lb://USERS
              predicates:
                - Host=L14532.xyz.com
                - Path=/users/**
            - id: providers
              uri: lb://PROVIDERS
              predicates:
                - Host=L14532.cts.com
                - Path=/providers/**
            - id: reviews-streaks
              uri: lb://REVIEWSTREAKS
              predicates:
                - Host=L14532.cts.com
                - Path=/review-streaks/**
    logging:
      level:
        web: error
    eureka:
      client:
        fetch-registry: true
        register-with-eureka: true



<!-- end snippet -->

After mentioning the hostname also the request still not getting forwarded and application gateway is trying to find the page in src/resources like `spring mvc` and after not finding the page it is throwing **404 not found error**. And if I not mention the host name application gateway throws "L14532.xyz.com" could not be resolved. And throws **500 Internal Server Error**. And all this goes away if I try this project in my home computer where the host name is `localhost`. How can I solve this error.

answers.title: How to set per message TTL with RabbitTemplate?
answers.body:
You can create MessagePostProcessor and use it in you rabbitTemplate:

final String message = "message";
final MessagePostProcessor messagePostProcessor = new MyMessagePostProcessor(10000);
rabbitTemplate.convertAndSend("my.queue", "routingKey", message, messagePostProcessor);

This will catch you message, apply changes and send further.

public class MyMessagePostProcessor implements MessagePostProcessor {

    private final Integer ttl;

    public MyMessagePostProcessor(final Integer ttl) {
        this.ttl = ttl;
    }

    @Override
    public Message postProcessMessage(final Message message) throws AmqpException {
        message.getMessageProperties().getHeaders().put("expiration", ttl.toString());
        return message;
    }
}

answers.title: How to set per message TTL with RabbitTemplate?
answers.body:
Just to have a little workaround:

@Autowired
   private RabbitTemplate   rabbit;

   @Autowired
   private MessageConverter jsonMessageConverter;

   public void produce() {

      rabbit.setExchange("My.Exchange");
      rabbit.setRoutingKey("R.K");
      rabbit.setMessageConverter(jsonMessageConverter);
      MessageProperties props = new MessageProperties();
      props.setExpiration(Long.toString(expiration));
      Message toSend = new Message(message.toString().getBytes(), props);
      rabbit.send(toSend);
   }

answers.body_markdown:
If you're about to use `MessagePostProcessor` solution, you should add properties to your message instead of headers.

    message.getMessageProperties().setExpiration(ttl.toString());

                    RabbitMqConfig.RK,
                    String.valueOf(body),

              message.getMessageProperties().setExpiration(String.valueOf(1000));
